div.p: TREASVRE OF KNOWLEDGE: SPRINGING FROM THE fountaine of godlineſſe, which is the word of God.

p.hi: A LITTLE CATECHISME, wherin is handled the doctrine of the knowledge of God in Ieſus Chriſt.

div.p: Alſo a briefe and pithie Expoſition of the ten Commandements of Almightie God, the knowledge of the couenant of grace, the doctrine of the Sacraments, the Lords, Prayer, faſting, holy feaſts and vowes, and wherein the eſtate of the elect and reprobate, from Luke 16. 12. is plainely expounded and declared in Queſtions and Anſwers, by the late faithfull Miniſter and ſeruant of Ieſus Chriſt,
WILLIAM DYKE.
LONDON, Printed by R. Field for Robert Mylbourne, and are to be ſold at the great South doore of Pauls. 1620.

div.head: A TREASVRE OF KNOWLEDGE, SPRINging from the fountaine of godlineſſe, which is the word of God.

p.hi: Queſtion. WHereupon ought faith and true religion to be grounded?

div.p: Anſwer. Vpon the written word of God, contained in the old and new Teſtaments. Eph. 2. 20.

p.hi: Q. Who is the author of theſe holy Scriptures?

div.p: A. God himſelfe Heb. 1. 1.

p.hi: Q. How came theſe Scriptures firſt to the Church from God?

div.p: A. By diuine inſpiration. 2. Tim. 3. 16. 2. Pet. 20. 21.

p.hi: Q. To what end were they giuen?

div.p:
A. Perfectly to teach vs what to beléeue to ſaluation, and how to liue well. 2. Tim.
3. 16. Ioh. 5. 39. 6. 68. Pſal. 119. 9. 105. Iohn 20. 31.

p.hi: Q. Of what authoritie be theſe holy Scriptures?

div.p: A. Of the higheſt authoritie, aboue all men and Angels. Gal. 1. 18.

p.hi: Q. What is the reaſon of this?

div.p: A. 1. Becauſe they are of God.
2. Becauſe they onely immediatly & directly bind the conſcience. Iam. 4. 12. Eſa. 33. 22.

p.hi: Q. Which be thoſe bookes of the holy Scriptures?

div.p: A. The old and new Teſtaments.

p.hi: Q. Which be thoſe of the old Teſtament?

div.p: A. The Law and the Prophets.

p.hi: Q. Which be thoſe Bookes of the Law?

p.hi: Q. How is it proued that theſe Scriptures are indeed the word of God?

div.p: A. 1. By the perfect concord betwéen all thoſe writings, notwithſtanding the diuerſitie of perſons by whom, places where, times when, and matter whereof they were written.
2. By the admirable maieſtie and force that is in them to change the hearts of men. Heb. 4. 12. 1. Cor. 14. 24. 25.
3. By the working of the Spirit in the hearts of Gods children, to aſſure them they are the Scriptures of God.

p.hi: Q. How proue you that the Apocryphall bookes are not the word of God?

div.p: A. 1. Becauſe they are not written in the Hebrew character, as all the books of the old Teſtament were.
2. Becauſe the ancient Church of the Iewes did neuer receiue them to be read or expounded in their publike aſſemblies. Act. 13. 15. 27. 15. 21.
3. The primitiue Church both Gréeke and Latine after the Apoſtles did neuer receiue them for Scripture.
4. They containe many things repugnant to holy Scriptures.

p.hi: Hitherto of the Scriptures▪
Q. What do you conſider of concerning God?

div.p: A. 1. His Nature. 2. His Attributes. 3. The Trinitie of Perſons. 4. His Workes.

p.hi: Q. What is God?

div.p: A. An eternall Eſſence, that hath being of himſelfe. Exod. 3. 14.

p.hi: Q. Of how many ſorts be his Attributes?
Q. What be his Attributes incommunicable?

row.cell: A. Two
Simpleneſſe,
of nature.
and
Infiniteneſſe

p.hi: Q. What is that which you call ſimpleneſſe of nature?

div.p: A. It is an eſſentiall propertie in God, whereby euery thing that is in God, is God himſelfe. 1. Peter. 3. 17. 1. Iohn 4. 16.

p.hi: Q. What do you conſider of his infiniteneſſe?
Q. What is his Greatneſſe?

div.p: A. It is an eſſentiall propertie in God, whereby he containeth all things, and is contained of nothing. 1. Kings 8. 27.

p.hi: Q. What is his infiniteneſſe in Eternitie?

div.p: A. It is an eſſentiall propertie in God, whereby he is the firſt and the laſt. Reuel. 1. 8

p.hi: Q. What be the attributes of God that are communicable?

div.p: A. Thoſe which he doth communicate to others, as power, wiſedome, mercy, and ſuch like. Exod. 34 6.

p.hi: Q. Are thoſe in men or Angels as they be in God?

div.p: A. No: in God they be eſſentiall, in vs by participiation: in him abſolutely perfect, in vs imperfect. 1. Cor. 13. 9. In him without meaſure, and in all fulneſſe, Iohn 1. 16. In vs by meaſure.

p.hi: Q. What is further to be conſidered of concerning God?

div.p: A. The Trinitie of Perſons.

p.hi: Q. What is a perſon in the Trinitie?

div.p: A. A diſtinct ſubſtance, hauing in it the whole Godhead. Iohn 14. 9. 16. Coloſ. 2. 9.

p.hi: Q. What is the Father?

div.p:
A. The firſt perſon in the Trinitie, who hath of himſelfe eternally begotten his onely
Sonne. Pſal. 2. 7.

p.hi: Q. What is the Sonne?

div.p: A. The ſecond perſon in the Trinitie, eternally begotten of the ſubſtance of the Father. Iohn 1. 18.

p.hi: Q. What is the holy Ghoſt?

div.p: A. The third perſon in the Trinitie, eternally procéeding from the Father and the Sonne. Iohn 15. 26.

p.hi: Q. Is euery one of theſe three perſons the true and Eternall God?

div.p: A. The Father is God. Rom. 1. 7. Iohn 17. 3. The Sonne is God. Eſay 9. 6. 7. Iohn 1. 1. 2. 3. 4. 1. Iohn 5. 20. The holy Ghoſt is God, becauſe the names, properties, nature, and actions of God are giuen vnto him. Act. 5. 3. 4. Gen. 1. 2. Eſay 61. 2. Act. 2. 28. 1. Cor. 2. 10. 11. 1. Cor. 12. 4. 8. 9. 10. 11.

p.hi: Q. Is any of theſe greater one then another?

div.p: A. No, they are all coequall and coeternal, of the ſelfe ſame infinite being, power, and maieſtic. Iohn. 5. 7.

p.hi: Q. How are theſe, being three, ſaid to be one?

div.p: A. They are one in being and eſſence, but thrée perſons and ſubſtances.

p.hi:
Q. Euery one of theſe being true God, are
there then more Gods then one?

div.p: A. No, there is but one onely God. Deut. 4. 6. 1. Sam. 2. 2. Eſay 45. 5. Epheſ. 4. 6. 1. Cor. 8. 5. 6.

p.hi: Q. What is the reaſon that theſe three are but one God?

div.p: A. Becauſe the Godhead is communicable to all the Perſons, but the Perſons are incommunicable. Iohn 14. 9.

p.hi: Q. What be the perſonall properties?

div.p: A. To the Father to beget: To the Sonne to be begotten: To the holy Ghoſt, to procéed from the Father and the Sonne. Iohn 1. 18. & 15. 26. Hitherto of the Trinitie.

p.hi: Q. What do you conſider of in the workes of God?

list.item: 2. The execution of the Decrée. Lam. 2. 17.

div.p: Q. What is Gods Decree?
A. It is the moſt perfect will of God, of euery thing. Epheſ. 1. 11.
Q. What do you conſider of in this Decree?
Generall is that which is generally of all things. Acts. 15. 18.
Speciall is that which is ſpecially of ſome things, as of men and Angels, called Predeſtination. Epheſ. 1. 5. Rom. 8. 30.

p.hi: Q. What is Predeſtination?

div.p: A. It is the Decrée of God, concerning the euerlaſting eſtate of men and Angels.

p.hi: Q. What are the parts of Predeſtination?

div.p: A. 1. Election. Epheſ. 1. 4. Rom. 9. 11. 23.
2. Reprobation. 1. Theſ. 5. 9. 1. Pet. 2. 8. Iud. 4. Rom. 9. 22.

p.hi: Q. What is election?

div.p: A. Gods eternall appointing of certaine men and Angels to eternall life. Rom. 9. 23.

p.hi: Q. What is Reprobation?

div.p: A. Gods eternall appointing of certaine men and Angels to deſtruction. Rom. 9. 22.

p.hi: Q. What is the cauſe of this Decree?

div.p: A. The will of God. Rom. 9. 18.

p.hi: Q. When did this Decree begin?

div.p: A. It was before the foundation of the word was layed, and therefore it is eternall. Epheſ. 1. 4. Iude 4. 2. Tim. 1. 9.

p.hi: Q. What is the end of Gods election?

div.p: A. The praiſe of his glorious Grace. Epheſ. 1. 6.

p.hi: Q. What is the end of Reprobation?

div.p: A. The praiſe of his glorious Iuſtice. Pro. 16. 4.

p.hi: Q. Can this Decree be altered?

div.p: A. No: but remaineth vnchangeably the ſame for euer. Rom. 9. 11. Iohn 13. 1. Iames 1. 17. Rom. 11. 29. Malach. 3. 6.

p.hi: Hitherto of the Decree.
Q. What is the execution of the Decree?

div.p: A. The fulfilling of that which is decréed. Ephe. 1. 11. Dan. 4. 21.

p.hi: Q. What are the parts of execution?

div.p: A. Two: Creation and Prouidence.

p.hi: Q. What is Creation?

div.p: A. The giuing of the firſt being, forme, and qualitie to euery Creature.

p.hi: Q. What are the parts of Creation?

list.item: 1. The rude maſſe of the world wherein all things were confounded & mingled one with another.
2. The beautifull frame and faſhion of the world made of this rude maſſe.

p.hi: Q. Whereof was the rude maſſe made?

div.p: A. Of nothing. Heb. 11. 3.

p.hi: Q. How was it kept and preſerued?

div.p: A. By the holy Ghoſt. Gen. 1. 2.

p.hi: Q. What do you conſider in the frame and faſhion of the world?

list.item: 1. The elements which are the moſt ſimple ſubſtāces.
2. The bodies which are compounded of the Elements.

p.hi: Q. What be thoſe Elements?

div.p: A. Fire, Water, Earth, Aire.

p.hi: Q. What vnderſtand you by the bodies compounded?

div.p: A. The reſt of the creatures made of the vneuen mixture of the Elements.

p.hi: Q. How many ſorts of creatures be there?
Q. How many ſorts of viſible creatures be there?

div.p: A. Two. Senſible. Inſenſible.

p.hi: Q. What do you conſider in the Creation of man.

div.p: A. His parts, ſexes, and dignities.

p.hi: Q. How many parts be there of man?

div.p: A. Two: Body and Soule. Eccleſ. 12. 17. 1. Theſ. 5. 23.

p.hi: Q. Whereof was the body made?

div.p: A. Of the duſt of the earth, and therefore mortall. Gen. 2. 7.

p.hi: Q. What is the Soule?

div.p: A. A ſpirituall ſubſtance, and therefore immortall. Gen. 2. 7.

p.hi: Q. Why is not the Soule mortall?

div.p: A. Becauſe it was not made of any of the Elements, it being frée from compoſition is alſo frée from decay and periſhing.

p.hi: Q. What are the diuerſe Sexes?

div.p: A. Two, male and female: and of either there was created but one. Gen. 1. 27. & 2. 22 Malach. 2. 15.

p.hi: Q. What are the dignities?

div.p: A. 1. To be made after Gods owne Image. 2. To haue power and dominion ouer the creatures. Gen. 1. 26. 27.

p.hi: Q. What vnderſtand you by the Image of God?

div.p: A. Perfection of knowledge and puritie. Coloſ. 3. 10. Ephe. 4. 24.

p.hi: Q. Who made the Angels?

div.p: A. In the ſixe dayes God alſo created them of nothing.

p.hi: Q. What conſider you in their creation?

div.p: A. Their nature, knowledge, power, and office.

p.hi: Q. What is their nature?

div.p: A. It is not of any corporall matter, but méerely ſpirituall and incorruptible. Heb. 1. 14.

p.hi: Q. What is their knowledge?

div.p: A. It is naturall, for they be intelligent ſpirits, in a farre higher degrée then is the ſpirit of man.
2. Experimentall.
3. By reuelation.

p.hi: Q. What is their power?

div.p: A. It is very great, yet it is limited to do onely what God will. 2. Theſſ. 1.

p.hi: Q. What is their office.

div.p: A. 1. To defend, protect, and deliuer the righteous. Act. 12. 7. 8. 11. 15. Pſal. 34. 7. 2. To deſtroy the wicked. 2. King. 19. 35. Act. 12. 23.

p.hi: Q. How many ſorts of Angels be there?

div.p: A. Two: good and bad.

p.hi: Q. How were they created?

div.p: A. They were all made Angels of light. Iude 6.

p.hi: Q. How came they bad?

div.p: A. Not by creation but by tranſgreſſon. Iude 6.

p.hi: Q. Whereby did God made all things?

div.p: A. By his word. Heb. 11. 3. Gen. 1.

p.hi: Q. In what eſtate were the reſt of the creatures made and placed?

div.p: A. They were all made good and perfect in their kinde. Gen. 1. 31.

p.hi: What was the end of all the workes which God made?

div.p: A. His onely glory. Rom. 11. 36. Pſal. 19. 1. 2. Hitherto of the Creation.

p.hi: Q. What is prouidence?

div.p: A. A moſt wiſe diſpoſing of all things to their proper and appointed ends.

p.hi: Q. How farre doth this prouidence extend it ſelfe?

div.p: A. 1. In generall to all things both ſmall and great. Matth. 10. 29.
2. In ſpecial to matters of chance. Pro. 16. 33

p.hi: Q. Is not God then the author of ſinne?

div.p: A. He that is goodneſſe it ſelfe cannot be author of any thing but of that which is perfectly good, and therefore doth that well and iuſtly which the inſtruments do ill and vnlawfully.

p.hi: Q. How doth Gods prouidence bring things to paſſe?

div.p: A. 1. Sometimes by meanes. Acts 27. 31.
2. Sometimes without meanes. Ruth 2. 3.

p.hi: Q. What conſider you in the meanes?

div.p: A. 1. Sometimes they are lawfull.
2. Sometimes indirect. Gen. 27. 6. 7. 8.

p.hi: Q. Of what things chiefly is this prouidence?

div.p: A. Of men and Angels.

p.hi: Q. What of them eſpecially is to be conſidered?

div.p: A. The fall of both; the repaire of man. Gen. 3. 1. 2. 3. 15. Iude 6. 2. Pet. 2. 4.

p.hi: Q. What do you conſider of the fall of man?

div.p: A. Two things; the cauſes of the fall, and the fall it ſelfe.

p.hi: Q. What be the cauſes?
Q. What was their fall?

div.p: A. A voluntary tranſgreſſion of that Law which God gaue them, from whence came originall and actuall ſinne.

p.hi: Q. What is originall ſinne?

div.p: A. A priuation of originall purity, and corruption of the powers and faculties of nature.

p.hi: Q. How is originall ſinne called in the Scriptures?

div.p:
A. The old man, concupiſcence, ſinne that
dwelleth in vs: the body of ſinne, the law of the members. Rom. 6. 6. 7. 7. 20. 23.

p.hi: Q. When doth this ſinne firſt begin in man?

div.p: A. In his conception. Pſal. 51. 5.

p.hi: Q. What is actuall ſinne?

div.p: A. It is the breaking of the Law of God, in thought, word, and déed.

p.hi: Q. Are all ſinnes equall?

div.p: A. The firſt motion is not ſo great a ſinne as the outward action: ſome are pardonable, ſome vnpardonable. Acts 5. 3. 4. Luke 12. 4. 7. 48. Matthew 12. 31. Heb. 6. 4. Iohn 5. 16.

p.hi: Q. What followed ſinne?

div.p: A. Two things; guilt and puniſhment.

p.hi: Q. What is that guilt?

div.p: A. It is the deſert of ſinne, whereby we become ſubiect to the wrath and puniſhment of God.

p.hi: Q. What doth this guiltineſſe worke in vs?

div.p: A. 1. It doth ſtill accuſe and worketh vnquietneſſe in the mind. Gen. 4. 7. Rom. 2. 15.
2. It is an horror and torment to the conſcience. Pro. 28. 1.

p.hi: Q. What is the remedy againſt this?

div.p: A. 1. To reſiſt and withſtand the firſt motion of ſinne.

2. To humble our ſelues to the Lord by
confeſſion and repentance for ſinne committed.

p.hi: Q. What is the puniſhment?

div.p: A. It is all euill vpon the ſinner, both in this life, and in the life to come.

p.hi: Q. What are the euils in this life?

div.p: A. 1. Ignorance, darkneſſe of mind, hardneſſe of heart, proneneſſe to ſinne. Eph. 4. 17. 18. 19.
2. Calamities and miſeries vpon the bodies, goods, or name. Deut. 28. 15. 16. 17. &c.

p.hi: Q. What is the euill in the life to come?

div.p: A. Euerlaſting deſtruction both of body and ſoule. Rom. 6. 21. 23.

p.hi: Q. Did this guilt and puniſhment reſt in Adam and went no further?

div.p: A. It did not reſt in him, but ſpread it ſelfe to all his poſterity. Rom. 5. 12. 13. 14.

p.hi: Q. What is the ſcope of this Scripture?

div.p: A. To ſhew that the ſinne of one mans eating the forbidden fruit is the ſinne of all men.

p.hi: Q. Why ſhould the poſterity of Adam be guilty of that ſinne they neuer did?

div.p: A. Becauſe all mankind was in Adams loynes when he ſinned, as in Abraham Leui is ſaid to haue payd tythes to Melchiſedech.

p.hi: Q. What followeth vpon this?

div.p: A. That by propagation of our laſt Parents we are partakers of the tranſgreſſion of our firſt Parents. Hitherto of the fall.

p.hi: Q. What is the repaire of man?

div.p: A. A reſtoring of mankind to a farre better eſtate then euer we had in Adam. Rom. 5. 15.

p.hi: Q. What is the way to recouer this eſtate?

div.p: A. Onely by faith in the couenant of grace.

p.hi: Q. How doth that appeare that faith is the onely way?

div.p: A. Becauſe the Scripture ſheweth that the Fathers before and vnder the Law and Goſpell, were by this way of faith and by no other, iuſtified, and ſaued. Gen. 15. 6. Heb. 13. 8.

p.hi: Q. To whom doth this reſtoring belong?

div.p: A. Onely to mankind, and not to the Angels that are fallen.

p.hi: Q. Why doth it not belong alſo vnto them?

div.p: A. 1. Becauſe the promiſe of reſtoring was made onely to man, and not to them. Gen. 3. 15.
2. Becauſe the reſtoring was wrought in the nature of man, and not of Angels. Hebr. 2. 16.

p.hi: Q. What are the outward meanes of this reſtoring?

div.p: A. The word of God preached, and the Sacraments rightly adminiſtred.

p.hi: Q. What are the parts of the word?

div.p: A. The Law, called the couenant of works.
The Goſpell, called the couenant of grace.

p.hi: Q. What doth the Law require?

div.p: A. Perfection in all things, which none can do in any thing.

p.hi: Q. If the Law cannot iuſtifie, what vſe is there of it?

div.p: A. Though it cannot iuſtifie, yet there is great vſe of it.
Firſt, to the vnregenerate.
1. To diſcouer their ſinne.
2. To aggrauate and increaſe it.
3. To pronounce the ſentence of death aainſt them, and ſo is a Schoolemaiſter to bring them to Chriſt. Gal. 3. 24.
Secondly, To the regenerate.
1. It is a light to ſhew and direct them how to liue aright after they be come to Chriſt. Pſal. 119. 105.
2. It doth quicken and ſtirre vp to obedience.
3. It kéepeth downe the rebellion of the fleſh in the beſt.

p.hi: Q. What rules are to be obſerued for the better vnderſtanding of the Law?

div.p: A. 1. In euery commandement there is a figuratiue ſpéech, whereby more is commanded or forbidden then is named.
2. In euery commandement there be two parts, affirmatiue and negatiue, whereof the one is expreſſed, and the other vnderſtood.
3. Whatſoeuer euery commandement commandeth or forbiddeth, it commandeth all meanes and occaſions thereunto, and forbiddeth the contrary.
4. The Law is ſpirituall, and therefore is giuen to rule and order as well the inward man as the outward.

p.hi: Q. Why is euery commandement ſet forth in the ſecond perſon and ſingular number, (thou?)

div.p: A. That euery particular man may know that God ſpeaketh to him.

p.hi: Q. How is the Law diuided?

div.p: A. Into two Tables, the firſt and the ſecond. Exod. 34. 1. Deut. 4. 13.

p.hi: Q. What is proper to the firſt Table?

div.p: A. 1. That intreateth of God and his worſhip onely.
2. The duties and ſinnes of the firſt Table are greater then the duties and ſinnes of the ſecond Table, if the compariſon be equall, otherwiſe not.
3. Euery commandement of the firſt Table haue their ſeueral reaſons annexed vnto thē.

p.hi: Q. Why are the reaſons of the commandement of the firſt Table ſet downe rather then the ſecond?

div.p: A. To ſhew that there is leſſe light left in vs of the worſhip of God, then of the duties we owe to our neighbour.

p.hi: Q. What doth the ſecond Table teach vs?

div.p: A. The duties of loue and righteouſneſſe to our neighbours, both in our generall and particular callings.

p.hi: Q. What is to be obſerued frō hence, that God hath ioyned theſe two Tables together?

div.p: A. That in that obedience which is pleaſing to God, the duties of both tables muſt be ioyned together, and neuer ſeuered. 1. Ioh. 4. 20. 21.

p.hi: Q. Rehearſe the words of the preface.

div.p: A. God ſpake all theſe words, ſaying, &c.

p.hi: Q. What is contained in theſe words?

div.p: A. The precept it ſelfe, and thrée ſeuerall reaſons ſet before it.

p.hi: Q. What is the firſt reaſon?

div.p: A. It is contained in theſe words, I am Iehouah, or the Lord; whereby God ſheweth that he hath abſolute power and iuſt right to command all, and therefore of right all are bound to obey whatſoeuer he commandeth.

p.hi: Q. What is the ſecond reaſon?

div.p: A. It is contained in theſe words, Thy God. In which God doth bind himſelfe by promiſe, to giue vs all good things here, & in the world to come eternal life; & therfore we are bound to obey him. Heb. 11. 16. Pſ. 144. 15.

p.hi: Q. What is the third reaſon?

div.p: A. It is contained in theſe words, Which brought thee out of the land of Egypt, &c. In which God puts the Iewes in mind what a great deliuerance he had giuen them, and therefore bound them to obey him.

p.hi: Q. How doth this reaſon concerne vs?

div.p: A. That deliuerance did ſhadow out our ſpiritual deliuerance from ſin and the diuel, and therfore we are ſtraightly bound to obey this law.

p.hi: Q. Rehearſe the firſt commandement.

div.p: A. Thou ſhalt haue no other gods, &c.

p.hi: Q. What is the ſum of this cōmandement?

div.p: A. The inward worſhip of God.

div.p: A. 1. A threatning of iudgement againſt the tranſgreſſors of this commandement, thereby to kéepe vs from falſe worſhip.

p.hi: Q. Rehearſe the third commandement.

div.p: A. Thou ſhalt not take the Name of the Lord thy God in vaine: for the Lord will not hold him guiltles that taketh his Name in vaine.

div.p: A. 1. The precept it ſelfe: 2. the reaſons of it.

p.hi: Q. What is the ſumme of this commandement?

div.p: A. The right vſe of the holy Name of God, and of all the parts of his worſhip.

p.hi: Q. What is meant by the Name of God?

div.p: A. All that whereby he is made knowne vnto vs, as his titles, attributes, workes, word, and Sacraments. Pſal. 8. 1. Rom. 2. 24. Leuit. 22. 2.

p.hi: Q. How is the ſecond Table diuided?

div.p: A. 1. Into thoſe commandements which concerne ſpeciall duties to ſpeciall perſons, as the fifth commandement.
2. Into thoſe which concerne generall duties vnto all, as the laſt fiue commandements.

p.hi: Q. Rehearſe the fifth commandement?

div.p: A. Honour thy father and thy mother, that thy dayes may be long in the land, which the Lord thy God giueth thée.

p.hi: Q. What is meant by father and mother?

div.p: A. Our naturall parents, and all others that be aboue vs, in gifts, calling, or age.

To be examples of looſe life.

p.hi: Q. What is the reaſon that is put to this commandement?

div.p: A. It containes a promiſe of a long life to thoſe that be dutifull & obedient to parents.

p.hi: Q. Rehearſe the ſixth commandement.

div.p: A. Thou ſhalt not kill.

p.hi: Q. What is the ſum of this cōmandement?

div.p: A. All generall duties concerning the life and perſon of our neighbour.

p.hi: Q. What is particularly

row.cell: To kill, or any way to procure hurts or wounds to their or our owne bodies. Gen 4. 8. 2. Sam. 11. 15. & 12 9. Leuit. 24. 19, 20.
To preſerue his and our owne perſon, life, and health. Iob 29. 15. Luke 10. 34, 35.
Exceſſiue correction.
To hurt the impotent.
To ouerworke men.
To deny ſuccour and reliefe to thoſe that are in diſtreſſe. Eſa. 58 7.
To giue to thoſe in néed. Eccleſ. 11. 2.
Crueltie and hard vſage of the creature.
Mercie. Prou. 12. 10.
All threatnings, bitter & prouoking ſpéeches. Math. 5. 22. 2. Sam 6. 20. Pro. 12. 18.
Courteous and amiable ſpéeches.
Soft and friendly anſwers. Prou. 15. 1.
To mocke at the meane condition of others. 1. Sam. 17. 18.
A wrathfull & frowning countenance. Ge. 4. 5, 6.
A louing & friendly countenance.
A ſcornful nodding the head: to gnaſh the téeth at one. Math. 27. 39. Acts 7. 54.
Anger without cauſe, or paſt meaſure. Math. 5. 22.
To be ſlow to anger. Iam. 1. 19.
Hatred, enuie, frowardneſſe.
Loue, méekneſſe,
long-ſuffering. Epheſ. 4. 2. 26. Col. 3. 12, 13.
To eate & drink that which ouerthrowes our health.
Surfetting.
To eate out of ſeaſon. Eccleſ. 10. 16.
Seaſonable diet.

p.hi: Q. Rehearſe the ſeuenth commandement.

div.p: A. Thou ſhalt not commit adulterie.

p.hi: Q. What is the ſumme of this commandement?

div.p: A. Chaſtitie of bodie and mind.

p.hi: Q. What is particularly forbidden and commanded?

row.cell: All vncleanneſſe.
Chaſtitie of body and ſpirit.
Adulterie, fornication, inceſt. Leuit. 19. 29. Deut. 23. 17. & 22. 28. 1. Theſſ. 4. 3.
Honeſt and chaſte life both in ſingle and maried eſtate. 1. Theſ. 4. 4
To haue many wiues at once, Polygamie. Gen. 2. 22. 24. Leu. 18. 18. 1. Tim. 3. 2.
One wife for one huſband. Mal. 2. 15. 1. Cor. 7. 2.
To entice or inforce
any to vncleanneſſe. 2. Sam. 13. 11. 14.
The exceſſiue and immoderate vſe of the mariage bed.
The moderate and ſanctified vſe of the wife.
Buggery, man with man, man or woman with beaſts. Leuit. 18. 23. Rom. 1. 26, 27.
The naturall vſe of that kind which God hath appointed.
Vnchaſte luſts, burning deſires. Mat. 5. 28 1. Cor. 7. 9. 1. Theſ. 4. 5.
To be chaſte in ſpirit.
Idleneſſe, gluttony, drunkenneſſe. Ezech. 16. 49. Eſa. 5. 22. Geneſ. 19. 32.
Temperance, ſobrietie. Acts 24. 25.
Men to weare womens apparell, women mens.
Modeſt, decent, and comely apparel. 1. Tim 2. 9.
Wanton and newfangled attires. Deut. 22. 5. Eſ. 3. 16. Zeph. 1. 8
Wanton diet, & ſuch meates and drinks as prouoke luſt. Ezec. 16. 49. Eſa. 5. 11. Eccl. 10. 16
Sober diet, to eate for ſtrength. Eccleſ. 10 17.
Wanton ſpéeches, playes, & amourous bookes. 1. Cor. 15. 33.
Modeſt and chaſte talke. Epheſ. 5. 3. 4.
Wanton looks and geſtures.
To make a couenant with our eyes. Iob. 31. 1.
To companie with thoſe that are light & wanton. Gen. 39. 10. 2. Pet. 2. 14.
Mixt and wanton dancing, wandring or gadding abroad, to ſée or to be ſéene. Gen. 34. 1.
The maried to defraud one another. 1. Cor. 7. 5.
Due beneuolence. 1. Cor. 7. 3.
Separation of man and wife. 1. Cor. 7. 5.
To liue together. 1. Cor. 7. 5.
Not to marie when there is néed. 1. Cor. 7. 9.
To marrie in the Lord. 1. Cor. 7. 39.

p.hi: Q. Rehearſe the eight commandement?

div.p: A. Thou ſhalt not ſteale.

p.hi: Q. What is the ſumme of this commandement?

div.p: A. All generall duties to men, in reſpect of their goods.

p.hi: Q. What is particularly

row.cell: To take away our neighbours goods by robbery, oppreſſion, or fraud. Leuit. 6. 2. 1. Theſſ. 4. 6.
To preſerue and defend their goods. Deut. 22. 1. 2. 3. 1. Sam. 25. 7. 15. 16.
To withhold
To reſtore
Pledges:
Pledges:
Things left with vs to kéepe, things foūd, borrowed. Deut. 24. 12. Exod. 22. 26. Leuit. 6. 2. 3. Pſal. 37. 21
Things left with vs to kéepe, found, or borrowed.
Prodigall and waſtfull ſpending.
Frugalitie. Iohn 6. 12.
Niggardlineſſe to ſpare more then is iuſt. Prou. 11. 24.
Liberality. Eſay 32. 8.
Deſire of our neighbours goods. Math. 15. 19. 1. Tim. 6. 9. 10.
Diſcōtentednes with our preſent eſtate.
To be content with things preſent. 1. Pet. 5. 8. 1. Tim. 6. 8. Phil. 4. 11. 12.

p.hi: Q. Rehearſe the ninth commandement.

div.p: A. Thou ſhalt not beare falſe witneſſe againſt thy neighbour.

p.hi: Q. What is the ſumme of this commandement?

div.p: A. All generall duties in reſpect of his good name.

p.hi: Q. What is particularly

row.cell: To witneſſe falſly againſt our neighbours. Prou. 19. 5.
To witneſſe the truth.
Lying, diſſembling, talebearing, backbyting, ſlandering, Rom. 1. 29. 30. Leuit. 19. 16.
To reioyce at the good report of another.
Raſh cenſuring and iudging. Matth. 7. 1. 2.
To ſpeake of ſecret faults to their diſgrace. Prou. 11. 13.
To conceale faults.
To wreſt words to a contrary ſence and meaning. Math. 26. 61.
To interpret things ſpoken or done in the worſt part.
To take doubtfull things in ye beſt ſence. Gen. 37. 33. 1. Cor. 13. 7.

To ſpeake the truth,
yet with a purpoſe to hurt.
To ſpeake of mens infirmities, & meane conditions, to their diſgrace. 1. Sam. 17. 28.
To commend the good parts and gifts of God in them to others. Prou. 27. 2.
To iuſtifie the euill, and to condemne the good. Prou. 17. 28.
To iuſtifie the good and to condemne the euill. Pſal. 15. 4.
To beléeue all reports and tales Exod. 2 〈…〉 1. Sam. 24. 10. Pſal. 15. 3.
To reiect the tale bearer. Prou. 25. 23.
To be ſilent when our neighbours are euill ſpoken of.
To ſpeake in their defence. Prou. 31. 8.
Euill ſurmiſes, ſuſpitions without ground, enuie, emulation. 1. Tim. 6. 4. Acts 28. 4. 2. 13. 1. Sam. 1. 13. Gen. 37. 11. 1. Sam. 17. 28.
Alwayes to thinke the beſt, and in loue to couer and paſſe by offences. Prou. 10. 12. 1. Cor. 13. 5.

p.hi: Q. Rehearſe the tenth commandement.

div.p:
A. Thou ſhalt not couet thy neighbours houſe, neither ſhalt thou couet thy neighbours wife, nor his ſeruant, nor his maide,
nor his oxe, nor his aſſe, neither any thing that is thy neighbours.

p.hi: Q. What difference betweene this and the former commandements?

div.p: A. The former forbid the outward action of ſinne with the conſent.
This forbids the firſt motion of ſin without the conſent.

p.hi: Q. What is particularly

row.cell: All thoughts and deſires againſt our neighbours, without conſent. Rom. 7. 7.
That all our thoughts and deſires be for the good of our neighbour. 1. Tim. 1. 8. 1. Theſſ. 5. 23.
The firſt motions of ſinne with the leaſt liking.
Oppoſition againſt the firſt touch and tender of euill. Gal. 5. 17.

p.hi: Q. Is all deſire here forbidden?

div.p: A. No, but that which is after ſomething of our neighbours.

p.hi: Q. Are euill thoughts againſt God forbidden in this commandement?

div.p: A. They are forbidden in the firſt commandement, but in this onely ſuch as be againſt our neighbour.

p.hi: Q. How many degrees of ſinne are there forbidden in the Law?

div.p: A. Thrée.
The firſt motion in the firſt and in the tenth commandements, againſt God and againſt our neighbour.
The conſent and outward action of ſinne in the reſt.

p.hi: Q. Where elſe do you find theſe degrees of ſinne?

div.p: A. Acts 5. 34.

p.hi: Q. What is the ſumme of the Law?

div.p: A. To loue the Lord with all our whole hearts, and our neighbour as our ſelfe.

p.hi: Q. What loue of God is commanded in the Law?

div.p: A. That which is perfect, which muſt be with all the powers and faculties of ſoule & body. Marke 12. 30.

p.hi: Q. What loue to our neighbour is commanded?

div.p: A. To loue him as our ſelfe, to ſtudie for his good as for our owne. Marke 12. 31. So much of the Couenant of workes.

p.hi: Q. What is the couenant of grace?

div.p: A. That God will giue vnto vs life euerlaſting through Ieſus Chriſt, if we beléeue in him. Ierem. 31. 32. 33.

p.hi: Q. Why was this couenant of grace giuen?

div.p: A. Becauſe the couenant of workes cannot (by reaſon of the infirmitie of the fleſh) giue life vnto any. Rom. 8. 3.

p.hi: Q. What is the ſumme of this new couenant?

div.p: A. The ſecond perſon in Trinity, Chriſt Ieſus the onely Sonne of God.

p.hi: Q. What do you conſider of in Chriſt?

div.p: A. His perſon and his office.

p.hi: Q. What conſider you in his perſon?

div.p: A. 1. His Godhead that maketh a perſon, and that in honour and dignity he is farre aboue all men and Angels.
2. His Manhood which hath ſubſtance in the perſon of the Godhead.

p.hi: Q. What conſider you of his Godhead?

div.p: A. That he is the onely naturall Sonne of God his Father, equall with the Father and the holy Ghoſt.

p.hi: Q. What of his Manhood?

div.p: A. That the diuine nature tooke to himſelfe a reaſonable ſoule and body. Hebrewes 2. 16.

p.hi: Q. Was there no change of theſe natures one into another, nor any mixture of them?

div.p:
A. There was no change of the natures themſelues, nor of their eſſentiall properties, but theſe two were vnited into one
perſon, yet diſtinguiſhed in ſubſtance, properties, and actions.

p.hi: Q. Why muſt Chriſt be man?

div.p: A. 1. Becauſe he muſt be fit to die.
2. Becauſe by man the ſinne was committed, therefore by man the recompence muſt be made, the iuſtice of God ſo requiring.

p.hi: Q. Why muſt Chriſt be God?

div.p: A. Becauſe he might be able to pay the infinite ranſome for vs.

p.hi: Q. When were thoſe two natures vnited?

div.p: A. From the firſt moment of Chriſts conception in the wombe of the virgine Mary.

p.hi: Q. What is the vſe of the coniunction of theſe two natures?

div.p: A. That the manhood of our Sauiour Chriſt, being perſonally vnited to the Godhead, the obedience of Chriſt muſt be of infinite merite, as being the obedience of God. So much of his perſon.

p.hi: Q. What is his office?

div.p: A. A Mediator.

p.hi: Q. What name is giuen to him in regard of his office?

div.p: A. Chriſt.

p.hi: Q. What doth that name ſignifie?

div.p: A. Annointed.

p.hi: Q. How many Mediators are there?

div.p: A. Onely one, Chriſt Ieſus. 1. Tim. 2. 5.

p.hi: Q. Why muſt Chriſt alone be Mediator?

div.p: A. Becauſe Chriſt alone did partake both the nature of God and man, which is of neceſſitie for him that ſhould mediate betwéen both.

p.hi: Q. What be the parts of his Mediatorſhip?

div.p: A. His Prieſthood and his Kingdome.

p.hi: Q. What be the works of his Prieſthood?

div.p: A. 1. Teaching.
2. Meriting.

p.hi: Q. How did Chriſt teach the will of his Father?

div.p: A. 1. By himſelfe, in his owne perſonall miniſtery.
2. By his ſeruants before and after him. 1. Pet. 3. 18, 19. Luke 10. 16.

p.hi: Q. What is the other worke of his Prieſthood?

div.p: A. The meriting of our redemption.

p.hi: Q. How did he performe that?
Q. What were the actions which he did in his baſe eſtate?

div.p: A. 1. Suffering. 2. Fulfilling.

p.hi: Q. What was his ſuffering?

div.p: A. That in body and ſoule he ſuffered the vttermoſt of Gods wrath, which was due vnto vs for our ſinnes. Eſa. 53. 5. 6. 8. Mat. 26. where at large is ſet out the whole ſtorie and all the parts of his ſufferings.

p.hi: Q. What vnderſtand you by fulfilling?

div.p: A. The perfect kéeping of the whole Law. Math. 3. 5.

p.hi: Q. What are the actions which he did in his glorie?

div.p: A. His reſurrection, aſcenſion, ſitting at the right hand of his Father. Rom. 1. 4. 8. 34. Acts 1. 9.

p.hi: Q. What fruite and benefit is there vnto vs by theſe works of his Prieſthood?
Q. What is redemption?

div.p: A. To be deliuered from the ſtate of ſinne and death, and reſtored to righteouſnes and eternall life. Col. 1. 13. Gal. 5. 5. Heb. 9. 12.

p.hi: Q. What be the parts of redemption?
Q. What is Iuſtification?

div.p: A. To be deliuered from the guilt of all ſinne, and to be made partakers of the righteouſneſſe of Chriſt.

p.hi: Q. What are the parts of Iuſtification?

list.item: 1. Remiſſion of ſinnes. Col. 1. 14. 2. Cor. 5. 19. Heb. 9. 26. 28.
2. Imputation of Chriſt his righteouſnes. Coloſſ. 2. 13. Rom. 4. 3. 6.

p.hi: Q. What is remiſſion?

div.p: A. The vtter aboliſhing of all ſin by the death of Chriſt. 1. Iohn 3. 5. Heb. 9. 26.

p.hi: Q. What is imputation?

div.p: A. A reckoning of Chriſts righteouſneſſe for our owne.

p.hi: Q. What is ſanctification?

div.p: A. To be frée from the tyrannie and bondage of ſinne, and to be reſtored to righteouſneſſe.

p.hi: Q. What are the parts of ſanctification?
Q. What is mortification?
A. A ſubduing of the power of ſinne. Rom. 8. 12.
Q. What is quickning?

div.p: A. A renewing of vs to newneſſe of life. Rom. 6. 4. 5.

p.hi: Q. What is Interceſſion?

div.p: A. A taking away of all pollution frō our obediēce, through the merits of Chriſt. 1. Ioh. 2. 1. and a continuall intermediating for vs to God.

p.hi: Q. What is the other part of his Mediatorſhip?

div.p: A.His Kingdome, whereby all the works of his Prieſthood are made profitable vnto vs.

p.hi: Q. What is to be conſidered in that?

div.p: A. 1. The kingdome it ſelfe. 2. The adminiſtration of it.

p.hi: Q. What is to be conſidered in the kingdome it ſelfe?

list.label: A. Two things: that it is a kingdome of

p.hi: Q. What elſe conſider you in this kingdome?

div.p: A. 1. The greatneſſe of it. 2. The nature of it.

p.hi: Q. Wherein doth the greatnes of it conſiſt?

list.item: 1. The extent, which is infinite. Pſal. 28. 9.
2. The power of it, which is abſolute. Reuel. 3. 7.

p.hi: Q. Of what nature is this kingdome?
Q. Are not we partakers of this his Prieſthood and kingdome?

div.p: A. Yes: we are made Prieſts to offer vp ſpirituall ſacrifices acceptable to God by Ieſus Chriſt. 1. Pet. 2. 5.
Kings to ſubdue our owne rebellious affections. Reuel. 1. 6.

p.hi: Q. Wherein doth the adminiſtration of the kingdome conſiſt?

div.p: A. In things and perſons.

p.hi: Q. What be the things?

list.label: A. They be of two ſorts:

p.hi: Q. What be the inward?

div.p: A. The Spirit, peace, ioy, righteouſneſſe, and faith, which are giuen by the outward.

p.hi: Q. What is faith.

div.p: A. An aſſurance of the loue of God towards me in Chriſt Ieſus, that he is mine, and I am his. Iohn 20. 28. Rom. 8. 38. Cant. 2. 16. 6. 3. 7. 10.

p.hi: Q. What conſider you in faith?

div.p:
A. 1. That it is of God, and not of our
ſelues. Math. 16. 17.
2. That it is not in all, but onely in the elect. Acts 13. 48.
3. That it is knowne by the fruits, which are, obedience to Gods commandements. Iam. 2. 20. Iohn 14. 15.
4. That it is common to all the children of God, yet in a different meaſure. 2. Pet. 1. 1. 1. Cor. 12. 11.
5. It is not here perfect in any, but increaſeth and groweth dayly. Rom 1. 17.
6. The leaſt meaſure of it ſaueth. Math. 17. 20. It cannot be vtterly loſt. Rom. 11. 29. Luke 22. 32.

p.hi: Q. What meane you by the Spirit in this place?

div.p: A. The power of God, which workes in the hearts of men things which the naturall diſcourſe of reaſon cannot attaine vnto.

p.hi: Q. What is the diuers working of Gods Spirit in the Church?

list.item: 1. Common to the Elect and reprobate.

p.hi: Q. What is proper to both?

div.p:
A. Illumination, knowledge, gifts of preaching, hearing with ioy, and doing of many things. Heb. 6. 4. Math. 7. 22. 13. 20.
Marke 6. 20.

p.hi: Q. What is the worke of the Spirit proper to the Elect?

div.p: A. A particular faith, iuſtification, ſanctification of the Spirit.

p.hi: Q. What be the outward things in the kingdome of Chriſt?

div.p: A. 1. Such as God hath giuen vnto vs.
2. Such as we do giue vnto him for ſeruice according to his word.

p.hi: Q. What be thoſe things which he giueth vnto vs?

div.p: A. 1. The Miniſterie of the word.
2. Sacraments.
3. Cenſures of the Church.

p.hi: Q. What is the Miniſterie?

div.p: A. It is an ordinance of God in the Church, which he hath appointed for the opening and applying of the Scriptures, thereby to call men to the knowledge of ſaluation. Math. 21. 25.

p.hi: Q. What is a Sacrament?

div.p: A. It is a ſacred action of the whole Church, wherein by outward ſignes done according to the ordinance of God, inward things are offered to all, and exhibited onely to the faithful, to ſtrengthen their faith in the eternall Couenant.

p.hi: Q. What do you conſider in a Sacrament?

div.p: A. 1. Some things that are outward.
2. Some things that are inward.

p.hi: Q. What be outward things in a Sacrament?

div.p: A. 1. The perſons that do miniſter and receiue.
2. That which they do miniſter and receiue.

p.hi: Q. What be the perſons?

div.p: A. The Miniſter and the Communicants.

p.hi: Q. What belongs to the Miniſter?

div.p: A. Chiefly to conſecrate and deliuer the outward elements.

p.hi: Q. Wherein ſtands the conſecration?

div.p: A. 1. In declaring and opening the inſtitution of the Sacrament.
2. In prayer and thankſgiuing to God, the Church ioyning with him.

p.hi: Q. Is not the nature and ſubſtance of the element changed by this conſecration?

div.p: A. There is no change of the ſubſtance of the element: for then there were no Sacrament.

p.hi: Q. Is there then no difference betweene thoſe elements and others of that kind in common vſe?

div.p: A. None at all in ſubſtance, but onely in their vſe, during the time of yt preſent action.

p.hi: Q. Why then are the outward Elements called by the name of the thing ſignified, as bread to be called the body of Chriſt?

div.p: A. 1. To ſhew the vnſeparable coniunction of the things ſignified with the outward ſigne, to the worthy receiuer. 1. Cor. 10 16.
2. More fully to aſſure the worthy receiuer that he doth as verily receiue the things ſignified, as he doth the outward ſignes.

p.hi: Q. What is required before our receiuing the Sacrament?

div.p: A. Preparation.

p.hi: Q. Wherein ſtandeth that?

div.p: A. In Knowledge, Faith, Repentance.

p.hi: Q. What is required in the Action of receiuing?

div.p: A. 1. A reuerent behauiour.
2. To meditate of our owne miſery.
3. To thinke of the death and ſufferings of Chriſt.
4. Not to reſt in the outward Elements, but to lift vp our hearts to Chriſt.

p.hi: Q. What is required after the Sacrament?

div.p: A. 1. To examine our ſelues for comfort and benefit receiued by them, and to reioyce for the ſame, with thankſgiuing. Acts 8. 39.

2. Not finding our ſelues to haue profited
by by them, to iudge our ſelues, and be humbled. 1. Cor. 11. 30. 31.

p.hi: Q. How many Sacraments be there?

div.p: A. Onely two.

p.hi: Q. Why were there no more ordained?

div.p: A. Becauſe by theſe two we are aſſured of all graces.

p.hi: Q. Which is the firſt?

div.p: A. Baptiſme.

p.hi: Q. What is Baptiſme?

div.p: A. A Sacrament of the new couenant, whereby our entrance into the Church is ſealed vnto vs.

p.hi: Q. What is the outward ſigne in Baptiſme?

div.p: A. Water.

p.hi: Q. What doth that ſignifie?

div.p: A. Waſhing.

p.hi: Q. What agreement is there betweene the ſigne and the thing ſignified?

div.p: A. As water waſheth away the filth of the body, ſo doth the bloud of Chriſt cleanſe vs from all vnrighteouſneſſe, both originall and actuall.

p.hi: Q. What benefite haue we by Baptiſme?

list.item: 1. The forgiueneſſe of all our ſinnes.

p.hi: Q. Who are to be baptized?

div.p: A. The children of the faithfull, and thoſe which turne Chriſtians.

p.hi: Q. What is the Lords Supper?

div.p: A. It is the ſecond Sacrament of the new Teſtament, whereby is ſealed vnto vs our continuance and growth in Chriſt.

p.hi: Q What be the outward ſignes in a Sacrament?

div.p: A. Bread and wine.

p.hi: Q. What do they ſignifie?

div.p: A. The body and bloud of Chriſt.

p.hi: Q. What agreement is there betweene the ſignes and the thing ſignified?

div.p: A. As bread and wine nouriſheth our bodies, ſo doth the body and bloud of Chriſt nouriſh our ſoules to eternall life.

p.hi: Q. Are there diuerſe graces offered in Baptiſme and the Lords Supper?

div.p: A. No, but the ſame grace in both, but to diuerſe ends.

p.hi: Q. To whom doth this Sacrament belong?

div.p: A. To ſuch as be of the Church, that haue knowledge, and liue without ſcandall.

p.hi: Q. What is required of thoſe which come to this Sacrament?

div.p: A. 1. To be prepared.
2. How to behaue themſelues at it.
3. What is to be done after it.

p.hi: Q. What affections ought we to haue at the Communion?

div.p: A. Sorrow and gladneſſe.

p.hi: Q. Do you ſee any thing in the Sacrament to make you grieue?

div.p: A. Yes; the breaking of the bread, and powring out of the wine.

p.hi: Q. How doth that moue vs to mourne?

div.p: A. The breaking of the bread and pouring out of the wine, do ſet forth before vs the crucifying of Chriſt, which when we ſée, we ſhould be moued to mourne for our ſins, which haue cauſed all thoſe torments vpon our Sauiour Chriſt.

p.hi: Q. What is the cauſe we ſhould reioyce?

div.p: A. Becauſe by the death of Chriſt ſet forth in the Communion we are ſaued.

p.hi: Q. What benefite haue we by this Sacrament?

list.label: A. We are thereby more nearely and fully vnited vnto Chriſt, from whence cometh

p.hi: Q. What is common to the word and Sacraments, and what is proper to each?

div.p: A. Common to both, to increaſe faith.
Proper to the word, to begin faith.
Proper to the Sacraments more ſenſibly, fully and effectually to confirme faith, then the word alone without the Sacrament.

p.hi: Q. What is the reaſon of that?

div.p: A. Becauſe the Sacrament ſpeakes to more of our outward ſenſes then the word doth.

p.hi: Q. What vſe is there of the cenſures of the Church?

div.p: A. 1. To kéepe the members of the ſame in due obedience.
2. To put from amongſt them ſuch as liue not in conformitie to the will of God.

p.hi: Q. What is the end of them?

div.p: A. To bring men to repentance. 1. Cor. 5. 5.

p.hi: Q. How many ſorts are there?

div.p: A. Two, publicke, and priuate.

p.hi: Q. What are the priuate?

div.p: A. 1. Priuately and alone to admoniſh the offender. Matth. 18. 15.
2. If he repent not, to admoniſh him in the hearing of others. Matth. 18. 16.

p.hi: Q. What are the publicke?
Q. For what cauſe ought theſe cenſures to be adminiſtred?

div.p: A. 1. That the Name of God be not euill ſpoken of by ſuffering ſcandalous perſons amongſt them.
2. Leſt others be corrupted, and the weake fall away. 1. Cor. 5. 6. 7.
3. Leſt ſome without be hindred from ioyning them ſelues to the Church.

p.hi: Q. VVhat is the power of this cenſure?

div.p: A. To binde and looſe the ſinnes of men.

p.hi: Q. Who appointed theſe cenſures in the Church?

div.p: A. Our Sauiour Chriſt. They were practized alſo by the Apoſtles. Matth. 18. 15. 16. 17. 1. Cor. 5. 4. 5. 1. Tim. 1. 20.

p.hi: Hitherto of the things which God giueth vs.
Q. VVhat are thoſe that we giue vnto God?

div.p: A. Prayers, thankſgiuing, vowes, faſting, and holy feaſtings.

p.hi: Q. VVhat is prayer?

div.p: A. A calling vpon God alone in the name of Chriſt.

p.hi: Q. What ſhould moue vs to pray?

div.p: A. 1. Chiefly the commandement and promiſe of God. Pſal. 50. 15.
2. Gods fauourable acceptance of that duty.
3. Our owne wants, and the néeds of others.

p.hi: Q. In what manner muſt we pray?

div.p: A. In faith, and féeling of our owne wants.

p.hi: Q. For what things muſt we pray?

div.p: A. For things promiſed or commanded in the word of God.

p.hi: Q. What patterne is there in Scripture to direct vs in this worke?

div.p: A. That which Chriſt hath taught vs in the Goſpell. Matth. 6. 9.

p.hi: Q. VVhat is to be conſidered in that?

div.p: A. 1. The Preface.
2. The prayer it ſelfe.

p.hi: Q. VVhat is contained in the Preface, Our Father which art in heauen?
Q. How is God our Father?

div.p: A. By the meanes of Chriſt Ieſus.

p.hi: Q. What are the parts of this prayer?
Q. How many ſorts of Petitions be there?

list.item: 1. Such as concerne Gods glory alone.
2. Such as cōcerne our ſelues in the things of this life, & the life to come.

p.hi: Q. What do you conſider in the three firſt Petitions?

div.p: A. The firſt concernes Gods glory it ſelfe.
The other two the meanes whereby he is glorified.

p.hi: Q. What is the firſt Petition?

div.p: A. Hallowed be thy Name.

p.hi: Q. What is vnderſtood by the Name of God?

div.p: A. God himſelfe, his attributes, works, word, Sacraments, and Eccleſiaſticall cenſures. Rom. 2. 24.

p.hi: Q. What is meant by this word, Hallowed?

div.p: A. To put apart from common vſe, that which is holy.

p.hi: Q. What do we pray for in this petition?

div.p: A. 1. For the true knowledge of God, of his word, and his workes.
2. That we and others may ſanctifie God in beléeuing his word, though it ſéeme to vs impoſſible. Numb. 20. 12. Rom. 4. 20.
3. For feruent zeale to Gods houſe and ordinances. Pſal. 69. 9.
4. That we and others may glorifie God by holy conuerſation. 1. Pet. 2. 12.
5. That we and others may praiſe God for all his mercies.

p.hi: Q. What do we pray againſt?

div.p: A. 1. Ignorance and hardneſſe of heart.
2. Againſt all things that hinder Gods glorie. Eſa. 2. 11, 12, 13, 14, 15.
3. Againſt vnbeléefe and coldnes in Gods ſeruice.
4. Againſt prophaneneſſe of life, and vnthankfulneſſe.
5. Againſt giuing of honour and glorie to creatures.

p.hi: Q. Rehearſe the ſecond petition.

div.p: A. Thy kingdome come.

p.hi: Q. What is meant by kingdome?

div.p: A. The kingdome of power and grace.

p.hi: Q. VVhat deſire we touching the gouernment of the world?

div.p: A. That God by his ouer-ruling power would diſpoſe of all perſons and things as may be moſt for his owne glorie.

p.hi: Q. VVhat further?

div.p: A. That this gouernment may be for the enlargement of his kingdome here, and accompliſhment of it at the laſt day.

p.hi: Q. For what things do we pray in this petition?

div.p: A. 1. For the eſtabliſhment of all Gods ordinances, that the Word, Sacraments, and Cenſures may be rightly adminiſtred.
2. That God would furniſh his Church with fit Officers.
3. That ſo many of Iewes and Gentiles as belong to Chriſt, may be called.
4. For the powerful working of his Spirit, in renewing and quickning euery member of the Church.
5. That Chriſt would haſten his laſt comming.

p.hi: Q. VVhat do we pray againſt?

div.p: A. 1. The bondage of ſin and Satan in our ſelues and others.

2. All humane inuentions and traditions ſet vp in ſtead of Gods ordinances, and
made eſſentiall parts of his worſhip.
3. Againſt all counſels and powers which do oppoſe the Goſpell and Chriſts ordinances.

p.hi: Q. Rehearſe the third petition.

div.p: A. Thy will be done in earth as it is in heauen.

p.hi: Q. VVhat is meant by the will of God?

div.p: A. That which he hath reuealed in his word.

p.hi: Q. VVhat is meant by earth and heauen?

div.p: A. Thoſe things which are in earth and heauen.

p.hi: Q. VVhat do you here pray for?

div.p: A. 1. That we and all men may know Gods will, and do it.
2. Patience and chéerfulneſſe vnder the croſſc.
3. To denie and forſake our owne wils.

p.hi: Q. VVhat do we pray againſt?

div.p: A. Ignorance and diſobedience.

p.hi: Q. VVhat is meant by theſe words, In earth as it is in heauen?

div.p: A. That we and others may do the will of God, as the Angels do it.

p.hi: Q. How is that?

div.p: A. Moſt willingly, readily and ſpéedily.

p.hi: Q. Rehearſe the fourth petition.

div.p: A. Giue vs this day our dayly bread.

p.hi: Q. VVhat is meant by bread?

div.p: A. All outward things both for neceſſitie, and Chriſtian comfort and refection.

p.hi: Q. VVhat is here prayed for?

div.p: A. The enioying of outward bleſſings according to the will of God.

p.hi: Q. VVhat is prayed againſt?

div.p: A. The remouing and kéeping backe of euils, as ſhall ſéeme good to the Lord.

p.hi: Q. VVhat learne we from this word, Giue?

div.p: A. That we enioy all that we haue by gift, and not by deſert.

p.hi: Q. VVhy do we ſay, giue vs, when we haue it alreadie?

div.p: A. Becauſe the creature of it ſelfe hath no power to nouriſh. Deut. 8. 3.

p.hi: Q. VVhy is it added, for the day?

div.p: A. To teach vs to reſt contented with our preſent condition.

p.hi: Q. VVhy is it called ours?

div.p: A. To teach vs to vſe lawfull meanes for that we haue.

p.hi: Q. VVhat is meant by this word, dayly?

div.p: A. Things fit and agréeable to our condition and calling, and whereof we daily ſtand in néed of. Prou. 30. 8.

p.hi: Q. Rehearſe the fifth petition.

div.p: A. Forgiue vs our treſpaſſes.

p.hi: Q. VVhat is meant by this word, forgiue?

div.p: A. That our ſins may be couered, and not imputed. Pſal. 32. 1.

p.hi: Q. VVhat do you learne from theſe words, forgiue vs?

div.p: A. 1. That we are all guiltie of ſin, and that in none there is power to ſatisfie for the ſame.
2. That the expiating and putting out of this guilt, is onely by the death of Chriſt.
3. That in this life there is no perfection.
4. There muſt be a frée and humble confeſſion of our ſinnes.
5. That there is no iuſtification by works.
6. The way to remoue ſinne, is pardon by Chriſt.

p.hi: Q. VVhat do we here pray for?

div.p: A. 1. To haue knowledge and godly ſorrow for our ſinnes.
4. That Chriſts righteouſnes may be imputed vnto vs, and ſo we iuſtified.
3. For ioy in the holy Ghoſt, and inward peace of conſcience.
4. To be releaſed of the wrath of God.

p.hi: Q. VVhat pray we againſt?

div.p: A. The blindneſſe and ignorance of ſinne, hardneſſe of heart, feare, vnbeléefe. Ioh. 8. 18.

p.hi: Q. What is in theſe words, For euen we alſo forgiue them that treſpaſſe againſt vs?

div.p: A. That our readineſſe to forgiue others, doth aſſure vs that God doth forgiue vs. If we forgiue not, neither will God forgiue vs.

p.hi: Q. How are we ſaid to forgiue?

div.p: A. We forgiue not ſinne as it is a ſinne againſt God, but onely the wrong that is done vnto vs.

p.hi: Q. Rehearſe the ſixth petition.

div.p: A. Leade vs not into temptation, &c.

p.hi: Q. What is meant by temptation?

div.p: A. All allurements and inticements vnto ſinne, by the world, the fleſh, and the diuell.

p.hi: Q. What is meant by leading into temptation?

div.p: A. Not to be giuen ouer to the power of temptation.

p.hi: Q. How is God ſaid to tempt?

div.p: A. When as a moſt iuſt and righteous Iudge, he puniſheth one ſinne with another. 2. Theſſ. 2. 11. Rom. 1. 24.

p.hi: Q. What is meant by euill?

div.p: A. Satan and ſinne.

p.hi: Q. What do we pray againſt?

div.p: A. 1. The rebellion of our wicked nature.
2. Our proneneſſe to yéeld to ſinne and Satan.
3. The remnant of ſinne rebelling againſt the law of the mind.

p.hi: Q. What do you pray for?

div.p: A. That God would more and more ſet vs at libertie from ſinne and Satan.

p.hi: Q. Rehearſe the Thankſgiuing.

div.p: A. For thine is the kingdome, &c.

p.hi: Q. What is meant by kingdome?

div.p: A. Abſolute right and ſoueraigntie ouer all things.

p.hi: Q. What is meant by power?

div.p: A. The rule and gouernment of all things after the counſell of his owne will.

p.hi: Q. What is meant by glorie?

div.p: A. The praiſe which is due vnto him.

p.hi: Q. What is meant by this, for euer?

div.p: A. Eternitie.

p.hi: Q. What is meant by the word Amen?

div.p: A. 1. The earneſt deſire of the things prayed for.
2. The aſſurance of faith to receiue them in due time.

p.hi: Q. What be the other things that we do giue vnto God?

div.p: A. Faſting, holy Feaſts, Vowes.

p.hi: Q. What is a Faſt?

div.p:
A. An abſtinence commanded by God for the whole day, with cōfeſſion of ſins to God,
and prayer.

p.hi: Q. What conſider you in a Faſt?

div.p: A. 1. The Author. 2. The cauſe. 3. The parts. 4. The end of it.

p.hi: Q. Who is the Author of it?

div.p: A. God. Leuit. 23. 27. Iſa. 22. 12. Luk. 5. 35.

p.hi: Q. What are the cauſes of faſting?

div.p: A. 1. Iudgements already vpon vs, or neare at hand.
2. Buſineſſe of great moment, or importance to be done. Neh. 1. 4. 11. Heſt. 4. 16.

p.hi: Q. What be the parts of it?
Q. What conſider you in the outward?
Q. What is the outward ceremonie of it?

div.p: A. 1. To abſtaine from meate and drink.
2. To reſt from all labours, as vpon the Sabbath.
3. To mourne and to wéepe.
4. Separation of married perſons for a time. Ioel 2. 13. 17. Ezech. 7. 3. Exod. 19. 5. 1. Cor. 7. 5.

p.hi: Q. What is that in the outward which is matter of ſubſtance?

div.p:
A. Preaching, prayer, reading the Scriptures,
confeſſion of ſins to God. Nehe. 9. 3. 4.

p.hi: Q. What is the inward part of faſting?

div.p: A. A ſorrowfull, broken, and melting heart for ſinne. Ioel 2. 13.

p.hi: Q. What is the end of faſting?

div.p: 1. To witneſſe and teſtifie our repentance.
2. To make our prayers more feruent.
3. To remoue preſent iudgements, and to preuent thoſe that are neare.
4. To obtaine ſome great mercy at the hands of God.

p.hi: Q. How many kinds of faſts be there?
Q. What is the publicke?

div.p: A. When all the Churches of the land, or any one doth it by command of the Magiſtrate.

p.hi: Q. What is the priuate?

div.p: A. When a family or any one in it doth it.
Q. What is an holy feaſt?
A. It is a ſolemne thankſgiuing vnto God for ſome ſpecially mercy, obtained ſpecially by faſting. Numb. 10. 10. Nehe. 8. 9. 10. 11. 12. Zach. 8. 19. 2. Chro. 20. 26. 27. 28.

p.hi: Q. Wherein doth it conſiſt?

div.p: A. Partly in exerciſe outward & bodily: Partly in exerciſes of godlineſſe.

p.hi: Q. What is the outward?

div.p: A. A more liberall vſe of the creatures, as meates, drinkes, and apparell, then is ordinary: Nehe. 8. 10.

p.hi: Q. May we not eate and drinke more that day then on other dayes?

div.p: A. No; the excéeding is not in the quantitie of meate and drinke, but in a more dainty and bountifull diet then ordinary.

p.hi: Q. VVhy may not men eate more then vſually they do?

div.p: A. Becauſe we muſt vſe that moderation and ſobriety, as may the better fit vs to performe that duty of thankſgiuing to God.

p.hi: Q. What is the exerciſe of godlineſſe on that day?

div.p: A. It is in duty to God, or kindneſſe to men.

p.hi: Q. What is the duty to God?

div.p: A. Thankſgiuing to God for that preſent benefite, and that in an extraordinany manner, both in regard of gladneſſe and ioy in heart, as alſo in length of time.

p.hi: Q. What is that vnto men?

div.p: A. To ſend gifts to our friends, and portions to the poore. Nehe. 8. 10. Heſt. 9. 19. 22.

p.hi: Q. What is a vow?

div.p:
A. A ſolemne promiſe made to God by fit
perſons, of lawfull things. Pſal. 66. 13. 14. 1. Sam. 1. 11. Iudg. 11. 30. 31.
Q. Who are fit perſons to vow?
A. Such as haue knowledge, iudgement, and ability to diſcerne of a vow, and of the duties belonging to the performance of the ſame.

p.hi: Q. What is the end and vſe of a vow?

div.p: A. 1. To ſtrengthen our faith.
2. To teſtifie our thankfulneſſe to God.

p.hi: Hitherto of the things that belong to the kingdome of Chriſt.
Q. What be the perſons?

div.p: A. 1. Such officers as God hath appointed to gouerne his Church.
2. Such as are to be gouerned.

p.hi: Q. What be thoſe officers?

div.p: A. Such as deale in the Word and Sacraments, as Paſtors and Teachers, of what ranke ſoeuer they be.

p.hi: Q. What are thoſe to be gouerned?

div.p: A. The reſt of the people of what condition ſoeuer. Hitherto of the gouernment.

p.hi: Q. Rehearſe the Hiſtory of Lazarus?

div.p: A. And it was ſo that the beggar died, &c.

p.hi: Q. What is the doctrine of this place?

div.p: A. It doth ſet out the eſtate of the dead.

p.hi: Q. VVhat is here to be obſerued concerning that point?

div.p: A. Something common to good and bad.
Something proper to each.

p.hi: Q. VVhat is common to both?

div.p: A. Separation of body and ſoule, the naturall death, putrifaction of the body in the graue.

p.hi: Q. After death what is proper to each?

div.p: A. To the ſoule of the righteous a bleſſed eſtate. Ioh. 14. 3. Reue. 14. 13.
To the ſoule of the vnrighteous, the extreme torments of hell.

p.hi: Q. When do their ſoules paſſe to thoſe places?

div.p: A. Immediatly, and ſo ſoone as the ſoule leaues the body, it goeth to the place appointed. Luke 23. 43.

p.hi: Q. Rehearſe the place, &c.

div.p: A. 1. Cor. 15. 51. 52. 56. Behold I ſhew you a ſecret, &c.

p.hi: Q. What obſerue you from hence?

div.p: A. 1. That the bodies of the faithfull ſhall riſe againe.
2. In what manner they ſhall riſe.

p.hi: Q. By what argument doth the Apoſtle proue that the body ſhall riſe againe?

div.p: A. 1. Behold Chriſt is riſen.
2. That elſe the preaching of the Goſpell, our Baptiſme, and ſufferings ſhould be all in vaine.
3. That we ſhould be ſtill in our ſinnes, and moſt miſerable of all others.

p.hi: Q. How ſhall the body riſe?

div.p: A. It ſhall be changed from a body ſubiect to infirmity, diſhonour, and corruption, into a body, ſtrong, glorious and immortall. Phil. 3. 21.

p.hi: Q. Shall all be thus changed?

div.p: A. The dead ſhall firſt be raiſed, and then thoſe that are found aliue at his coming ſhall be thus changed. 1. Theſſ. 4. 15. 16.

p.hi: Q. Rehearſe the place of, &c.

div.p: A. Matth. 25. 31. 32. 33. 34. And when the Sonne of man cometh in his glory, &c.

p.hi: Q. VVhat is the ſcope of this place?

div.p: A. The laſt iudgement.

p.hi: Q. What haue we to conſider of that?

div.p: A. 1. The certainty of it.
2. The tokens going before it.

p.hi: Q. What is the certainty of it?
Q. What be the tokens going before it?

div.p: A. A 〈…〉 apoſtacie, multiplicity of hereſies:

p.hi: Q. How ſhall Chriſt come to iudgement?

div.p: A. With great power and glory. Mat. 25. 31

p.hi: Q. VVhat is the end of Chriſts coming?

div.p: A. 1. To giue ſentence.
2. To execute the ſame.

p.hi: Q. VVhat conſider you in the ſentence?

div.p: A. 1. That it is for the righteous, Come ye the bleſſed of my Father, inherite the kingdome.
2. That it is againſt the wicked, Go ye curſed.

p.hi: Q. What conſider you in the execution?

div.p: A. 1. The caſting of the wicked into hell.
2. The triumphant going of the righteous into heauen.

p.hi: Q. VVhat is to be conſidered in that their bleſſed eſtate?

div.p: A. 1. Fulneſſe of glory common to all.
2. An higher degrée and meaſure in that fulneſſe, ſpecially 〈…〉 .
